translations.english_us: How to administer your copy of Go.Data.
translations.french_fr: How to administer your copy of Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
A screen is available under the Admin > Audit Logs menu item of Go.Data to display all the changes performed on any record in the system. 

The following information will be displayed.
  1. Action - New, Modified, Deleted.
  2. Record ID - the ID of the record that was modified.
  3. Record name - is the name of the record like User, Person, etc.
  4. Time - the GMT time when the records was modified.
  5. Changes - shows the first section of the new and old values. Click Expand to see the information about the entire record.
  6. User - user who made the change
  7. User Role – role of the use who made the change
  8. IP Address – from what IP address was this change made.
This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

items.comment: Consulting the audit history of Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
A screen is available under the Admin > Languages menu item of Go.Data to display the following information about each language stored in the system:
  1. Name – the language name

To add a new Language, click Add button on the top of the page.

To modify a Language, click the actions button to the right of the Language and click Modify.

To delete a Language, click the actions button to the right of the Language and click Delete.

To view a Language, click the actions button to the right of the Language and click View.

To download the file for a language, click Download language file. After you modify the Language file as you see appropriate, you can upload it in the system by clicking Import Language File.

The current interface language for can be selected from the top right corner.

items.comment: Configuring Go.Data for multilingual usage.

translations.english_us: Advanced configuration of Go.Data for creating a network of multiple copies of the tool all exchanging data.
translations.french_fr: Advanced configuration of Go.Data for creating a network of multiple copies of the tool all exchanging data.

items.comment: Backing up and restoring Go.Data.
Manage what can connect to your copy of Go.Data.
Consult, block and wipe any devices that connect to your copy of Go.Data.
Configuring and executing synchronisation of Go.Data.
Manage the copies of Go.Data to which your copy can send information.

translations.english_us: Guidelines for using Go.Data and getting the most from the tool.
translations.french_fr: Guidelines for using Go.Data and getting the most from the tool.

items.comment: Best practice for keeping longer term records of information collected with Go.Data.
Best practice to keep and exchange copies of Go.Data information.
What constitutes best practice in Go.Data?
Ownership and privacy concerns for information stored in Go.Data.
Best practice for transitioning ownership of an instance of Go.Data between users.
Best practice for setting up an outbreak and distributing it to other copies of Go.Data.
Best practice for centralised and consistent reference data use.
Best practice for when you stop working with Go.Data.
View inconsistencies in outbreak data.

translations.english_us: A list of "documents" can be built up for a case, to specify any additional key documents and their associated identification numbers which are relevant for contact tracing work.  For instance, passport, driving license or other Government Id or a refugee camp identification document may be recorded here to supply supporting information for finding and correctly validating the identity of the case of interest.

items.comment: Working with documents related to a case.

translations.english_us:
The bespoke questionnaire designed for the current outbreak is displayed with the case record, allowing the user to complete it and provide the extra outbreak-specific information requested.

If the questionnaire needs to be modified (new, changed questions or questions removed) then this is done from the outbreak.  When removing a question, data provided for that question to date is not lost.

items.comment: Working with the case investigation questionnaire.

translations.english_us: To view lab results for an outbreak, click Cases -> View Lab results. The list can be sorted, filtered as any other list in the system, and then each individual result can be accessed.

items.comment: Working with the lab results of a case.

translations.english_us:
A line list of cases for the currently-selected outbreak is available using the Cases menu item within Go.Data:
  1. Last Name
  2. First Name
  3. Classification – value from Reference data
  4. Age – exact age of approximate age in years and months
  5. Gender – value from Reference data
To add a new Case, click Add button on the top of the page.

To add a Contact for a Case, click the actions button to the right and click Add Contact.

To add multiple Contacts for a Case, click the actions button to the right and click Bulk Add Contact.

To modify a Case, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click Modify.

To delete a Case, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click Delete.

To view a Case, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click View.

To convert a Case to a Contact, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click Convert to Contact.

To view Case movement on the map, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click View movement.

To view Case chronology, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click View chronology.

To view Case relationships, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click See relationships.

To view Case lab results, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click See lab results.

To view Case follow-ups, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click View Follow-ups.

To generate a Case empty investigation form, click the actions button to the right of the Case and click Export empty case investigation.

To see a report with cases without relationships, click the Quick actions button and click See cases without relationship.

To see the Onset report, click the Quick actions button and click Onset report.

To see the Onset long period report, click the Quick actions button and click Onset long period.

This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

Advance filtering is available by clicking the filter menu button on the right. To use wildcards in the search, use * for any latter or group of letters and ? for ay single letter.

A line list of cases is also available on a mobile device.

items.comment: Working with the case line list in Go.Data

translations.english_us: Go.Data is able to plot a map of the movement of a case over time using the addresses associated with the case and the dates of those addresses.  This functionality can only be delievered if latitude and longitude coordinates are available for the addresses.

items.comment: View the movements of a case on a map.

translations.english_us:
A number of reports are available for case data: -

Onset report - A report that highlights possible inconsistent data by showing all cases where the onset date is before the onset date of the case to which they are linked i.e. Case B became sick before Case A but we believe Case A was the source.

Onset long period - A report that highlights possible inconsistent data by showing all cases where the difference between onset dates for two linked records seems suspiciously long i.e. longer than a period configured at the outbreak level which may (for example) model the period that a case is shedding a disease.  This report should be used to highlight two linked individuals where we may have missed an intermediate individual.

Cases without relationships - A report that highlights possible inconsistent data by showing all cases that have no links i.e. there are missing contacts.

items.comment: Reports available on case data.

translations.english_us: Go.Data can deliver a timeline that shows all key dates in the history of that case.  This is available from the "Show chronology" button on the case screen and plots the date and the event such as "Date of Onset", "Classification 'Confirmed' Start Date" and any periods of hospitalisation or isolation.

items.comment: Chronological view of case activity.

translations.english_us:
Cluster List
A list of clusters is available from the Go.Data menu item Clusters.  This screen allows the user to create and maintain a series of named clusters that will be used to group exposures between cases/events and contacts that we consider linked epidemiologically.

The following information can be set for a cluster.
  1. Name
  2. Description

To modify a Cluster, click the actions button to the right of the Cluster and click Modify.

To delete a Cluster, click the actions button to the right of the Cluster and click Delete.

To view a Cluster, click the actions button to the right of the Cluster and click View.

To add a Cluster, click Add button on the top menu.

To view People and Events in cluster, click the actions button to the right of the Cluster and click View People.
This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.
Advance filtering is available by clicking the filter menu button on the right. To use wildcards in the search, use * for any latter or group of letters and ? for ay single letter.

Edit Cluster information
The following information can be edited for a Cluster:
  1. Name
  2. Description

items.comment: Clustering exposures in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
A list of contacts can be built up for a case by using the buttons within the case screen and on the case line list.  The user can select from existing contacts or opt to create a new one and a "bulk add contacts" option is available from the case line list for more rapid entry.

Contacts added to a case in this manner will be shown on the chain of transmission as linked and it is important to note that cases can only be created in Go.Data in the context of a case or event, there are no orphaned contacts.

A list of contacts linked to the currently-selected case is readily available via the "Relationships" button.

To copy contacts from one case to another, click Share exposure button, select what exposures you want to share and with what cases.

items.comment: Working with the contacts of a case.

translations.english_us:
A page show possible duplicate records is available directly from teh Go.Data main menu.

This page considers cases, contacts and events data and displays: -
  1. cases that are potential duplicates
  2. contacts that are potential duplicates
  3. events that are potential duplicates
Duplicate detection looks for a matching first and last name.

The user should never encounter mixed duplicates ( e.g cases with contacts / events ).

Functionality is provided to allow the user to merge two duplicate records.

items.comment: Handling duplicate case and contact data.

translations.english_us:
Event List
A list of "events" is available directly from the Go.Data main menu and allows the user to record significant occurrences such as a community gathering, funeral or family meeting in which transmission of disease may have occurred.  An event is therefore a placeholder until we are able to identify the individual present at the event and responsible for the transmission.
  1. Name
  2. Description
  3. Date of the event
To modify an Event, click the actions button to the right of the Event and click Modify.

To delete an Event, click the actions button to the right of the Event and click Delete.

To view an Event, click the actions button to the right of the Event and click View.

To add an Event, click Add button on the top menu.

To add a Contact for a Event, click the actions button to the right and click Add Contact.

To view Event chronology, click the actions button to the right of the Event and click View chronology.

To view Event relationships, click the actions button to the right of the Event and click See relationships.

To view Events without relationships, click the Quick actions button and click View events without relationships.

This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

Advance filtering is available by clicking the filter menu button on the right. To use wildcards in the search, use * for any latter or group of letters and ? for ay single letter.

Edit Event information
The following information can be edited for an Event:
  1. Name
  2. Date
  3. Date of reporting approximate
  4. Description
  5. Address - any number of addresses.
Each Event must have an address with the type Usual Place of Residence.

items.comment: Working with events in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
Go.Data platform uses an import system that allows users to use files to import various data, such as, cases, contacts, lab results, etc. The system supports a variety of files: csv, xls, xlsx, xml, ods, json.

In order to import data from a file, you need to go to the resource you’re interested to import, click on “Quick Actions” and “Import <resourceName>”, choose the file you want to import, optionally provide a file decrypt password (if the file is encrypted by another Go.Data instance) and upload the file. The system will read the file and offer you information on what the file contains (columns/headers and info about what’s inside the file).

In order for the system to understand the data you want to import, you need to provide a mapping between the imported file columns/headers and the resource fields. You need, at the very least to provide mapping information for the required fields. 
When a resource field is restricted to a list of values (not a free text field) that comes from reference data, you also need to map each value in the field to a system value.

When a resource field allows specifying a list (array) of entries, you can also specify the index of the entry you want to map by specifying the level.

After you’re done with the mapping, click “Import File”, the system will now start importing data. The system will inform you after the import is completed about the import status and will present errors for the entries that failed to be imported.

Example: Importing Case Data
  1. Go to the resource you’re interested to import (Case) and click “Quick Actions” > “Import case data”.
  2. Select the file you want to import (optionally provide a decrypt password if the file is encrypted by a Go.Data instance) and upload the file.
  3. You’ll be presented with a mapping interface that will allow you to map information from the file to resource information. Greyed out resource information (Model Information) represent required fields that need to be mapped in order for the resource to be imported successfully. The system will try to suggest mappings automatically, based on the field names; you can remove mapping or remap fields to your own preference.
  4. For the fields that use a restricted list of values (Reference Data), such as Gender, Occupation, etc. you need to map each value in the file to a valid Reference Data value. The system will also try to suggest mappings based on the labels.
  5. When a resource field allows specifying a list (array) of entries (such as Isolation Dates), you can also specify the index of the entry you want to map by specifying the level (in order to have Isolation Start Date and Isolation End Date in the same record, you need to specify same index (Level) for both entries; specifying different levels, will end up in the fields being mapped to different entries).
  6. After you’re done with the mapping, click “Import File”, the system will now start importing data. The system will inform you after the import is completed about the import status and will present errors for the entries that failed to be imported.
Cases can be similarly exported to a structured format.

items.comment: Extract and re-import case line list information in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
The following information can be edited for a case:

Personal Information

-          First name

-          Middle name

-          Last name

-          Gender

-          Phone number

-          Occupation

-          Age

-          Visual ID

Risk Information

-          Risk level

-          Date of reporting

-          Date of reporting approximate

-          Refused transfer to unit

-          Risk reason

Documents

-          Any number of document ID and type

Address

-          Any number of addresses. Each case must have an address with the type Usual Place of Residence.

Infection

-          Classification

-          Date of onset

-          Date of onset approximate

-          Date of becoming a case

-          Date of infection

-          Outcome

o   Outcome result

o   Date of outcome

o   Deceased

o   Was burial safety performed

o   Date of death

Questionnaire

-          A list of questions and answers for the case investigation based on outbreak settings

items.comment: Working with the edit view of a case.

translations.english_us:
From the case line list, the user can export an empty case investigation form for one or more selected cases.

This produces a ZIP file containing one PDF per case with the PDF name as a unique machine-readable code corresponding to the case record.

The PDF contains a paper version of the case form, to be employed when Go.Data cannot be used.  A QR code is also printed on the case form to allow the user to quickly navigate back to the electronic Go.Data record if their machine has a QR code reader.

The form is around 7 pages and contains fields for all details that appear in the electronic case form.

items.comment: Working with paper case investigation forms.

translations.english_us: Managing contacts within Go.Data and their follow-up.
translations.french_fr: Managing contacts within Go.Data and their follow-up.

translations.english_us:
Actions can be applied to multiple contact records at the same time by clicking the check boxes next to the desired contacts in the contact list and using the drop down arrow that appears at the top-left of the contact table to choose: -
  1. Export the selected contacts - export the contact records to a file in a format that can be reimported to other copies of Go.Data
  2. Export dossier for the selected contacts - export a ZIP file which contains one PDF per contact to create paper forms for contact investigation
  3. Export contact relationships - export the contact relationships to a file in a format that can be reimported to other copies of Go.Data, this is a flat file structure which lists all joins between contacts and cases/events
An option is also available to check or uncheck all contacts from the same menu.

items.comment: Work with multiple contact records at the same time.

translations.english_us: Go.Data can deliver a timeline that shows all key dates in the history of a contact.  This is available from the "Show chronology" button on the case screen and plots the date and the event such as "Date of Last Contact", "Follow Up Start Date" and any follow-up results.

items.comment: Viewing a timeline of significant events in the life of a contact.

translations.english_us: A list of "documents" can be built up for a contact, to specify any additional key documents and their associated identification numbers which are relevant for contact tracing work.  For instance, passport, driving license or other Government Id or a refugee camp identification document may be recorded here to supply supporting information for finding and correctly validating the identity of the contact of interest.

items.comment: Working with documents for a contact.

translations.english_us:
A list of all cases, contacts and events to which a contact is currently linked is available via the "View Exposures" button.  Individuals and events are listed and the user has the ability to view, modify or delete a relationship.

Multiple exposures of a contact to the same case/event are possible with Go.Data and contact tracing will use the most recent exposure to calculate the follow-up period (and also revert to the earlier exposure if the second is removed).

Exposures are the links between contacts and events which determine how the chains of transmission are constructed.

items.comment: Creating relationships from a contact to a case/event.

translations.english_us:
Contact List

A list of all contacts for the currently-selected outbreak is available under the Contacts > Contacts menu item of Go.Data.   This screen will display the following information about all Contacts stored in the system:
  1. Last Name
  2. First Name
  3. Age – exact age of approximate age in years and months
  4. Gender – value from Reference data
  5. Phone number
  6. Risk level
  7. Follow up final status
To add a Follow up for a Contact, click the actions button to the right and click Add Follow-up.

To modify a Contact, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click Modify.

To delete a Contact, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click Delete.

To view a Contact, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click View.

To convert a Contact to a Case, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click Convert to Case.

To view Contact movement on the map, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click View movement.

To view Contact chronology, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click View chronology.

To view Contact relationships, click the actions button to the right of the Contact and click See relationships.

To import Contact data, click the Quick actions button and click Import contact data.

To export Contact data, click the Quick actions button and click Export contact data.

This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

Advance filtering is available by clicking the filter menu button on the right. To use wildcards in the search, use * for any latter or group of letters and ? for ay single letter.

Edit Contact information
The following information can be edited for a Contact:

Personal Information
  1. First name
  2. Middle name
  3. Last name
  4. Gender
  5. Phone number
  6. Occupation
  7. Age
  8. Visual ID
  9. Date of reporting
  10. Date of reporting approximate
  11. Follow-up final status
  12. Risk level
  13. Reason
Documents
  1. Any number of document ID and type
Address
  1. Any number of addresses. Each Contact must have an address with the type Usual Place of Residence.
Questionnaire
  1. A list of questions and answers for the Contact investigation based on outbreak settings

items.comment: Working with the contact list.

translations.english_us: Go.Data is able to plot a map of the movement of a contact over time using the addresses associated with the contact and the dates of those addresses.  This functionality can only be delievered if latitude and longitude coordinates are available for the addresses.

items.comment: Viewing the movement of a contact over time.

translations.english_us:
Go.Data platform uses an import system that allows users to use files to import various data, such as, cases, contacts, lab results, etc. The system supports a variety of files: csv, xls, xlsx, xml, ods, json.

In order to import data from a file, you need to go to the resource you’re interested to import, click on “Quick Actions” and “Import <resourceName>”, choose the file you want to import, optionally provide a file decrypt password (if the file is encrypted by another Go.Data instance) and upload the file. The system will read the file and offer you information on what the file contains (columns/headers and info about what’s inside the file).

In order for the system to understand the data you want to import, you need to provide a mapping between the imported file columns/headers and the resource fields. You need, at the very least to provide mapping information for the required fields. 
When a resource field is restricted to a list of values (not a free text field) that comes from reference data, you also need to map each value in the field to a system value.

When a resource field allows specifying a list (array) of entries, you can also specify the index of the entry you want to map by specifying the level.

After you’re done with the mapping, click “Import File”, the system will now start importing data. The system will inform you after the import is completed about the import status and will present errors for the entries that failed to be imported.

Example: Importing Contact Data
  1. Go to the resource you’re interested to import (Contact) and click “Quick Actions” > “Import contact data”.
  2. Select the file you want to import (optionally provide a decrypt password if the file is encrypted by a Go.Data instance) and upload the file.
  3. You’ll be presented with a mapping interface that will allow you to map information from the file to resource information. Greyed out resource information (Model Information) represent required fields that need to be mapped in order for the resource to be imported successfully. The system will try to suggest mappings automatically, based on the field names; you can remove mapping or remap fields to your own preference.
  4. For the fields that use a restricted list of values (Reference Data), such as Gender, Occupation, etc. you need to map each value in the file to a valid Reference Data value. The system will also try to suggest mappings based on the labels.
  5. When a resource field allows specifying a list (array) of entries you can also specify the index of the entry you want to map by specifying the level.
  6. After you’re done with the mapping, click “Import File”, the system will now start importing data. The system will inform you after the import is completed about the import status and will present errors for the entries that failed to be imported.
The relationships for contacts can also be exported.

Contacts can be similarly exported to a structured format.

items.comment: Extracting and re-importing contact data.

translations.english_us:
Two dashboards are available to work with follow-up information: -
  1. Daily Follow-Ups available under the menu item Contacts > Daily Follow-Ups
  2. Follow-Up Dashboard available under the menu item Contacts > Follow-Up Dashboard
The first dashboard provides a tabular view of follow-up activity with one row per follow-up to be performed.  The user can filter for different days of follow-up work and generate, print and export follow-up records from this screen.  It is this follow-up data which is sent to a mobile phone for performing follow/up on a mobile device.  Note that individual follow-ups can also be generated from a phone/tablet itself using the Go.Data application.  Bulk operations against follow-up records are also possible to modify multiple records at the same time.

The second dashboard provides a more visual overview of follow-up work with a time slider of the outbreak period and colour-coded cells against each contact name indicating when follow-up has/is due to occur and the result of follow-up.  Clicking on the cells allows the user to modify the follow-up record.

Individual follow- up records can be accessed and modified from both views and data can also be exported.

items.comment: Working with an overview of follow-up activity.

translations.english_us:
Follow-ups are generated in one of three ways: 
  1. On a smart phone/tablet, the user can generate a follow-up for a contact
  2. On the contact list/record within the Go.Data computer application the user can ask to add a follow-up for a contact
  3. On the Daily Follow-Up dashboard, the user can bulk generate a set of contact follow-up records between a given date range
For the last option, the system will identify all contacts who require follow-up based on their date of last exposure and proceed accordingly.  It will also continue to keep a contact on the follow-up list after the period of follow-up has normally ended to allow a contact tracer to explicitly approve that they can be removed by setting a final "outcome" status for the contact.

Follow-up records once generated on the computer can then be synchronised with a smart phone/tablet if that device is to be used for follow-up.

items.comment: Creating follow-ups for a contact.

translations.english_us:
The following information can be edited for a Contact:

Personal Information
- First name
- Middle name
- Last name
- Gender
- Phone number
- Occupation
- Age
- Visual ID
- Date of reporting
- Date of reporting approximate
- Follow-up final status
- Risk level
- Reason

Documents
- Any number of document ID and type

Address
- Any number of addresses. Each Contact must have an address with the type Usual Place of Residence.

Questionnaire
- A list of questions and answers for the Contact investigation based on outbreak settings

items.comment: Working with the edit mode for a contact.

translations.english_us:
Follow-up is performed on either smart phone/table using the Go.Data app or on a computer using the installed software.  In all situations the user must choose the contact follow-up record of interest and opt to modify it to set the status and record additional details.  When follow-up is performed on a mobile device, the information is sent back to the parent copy of Go.Data when that phone/tablet next performs a synchronisation.

When generating a bulk of follow-ups for the future using the Daily Follow-Up screen on a computer, the system will create a set of follow-up records with status "no data" as placeholders for the follow-up to be performed.

items.comment: Performing follow-up on computer or mobile device.

translations.english_us:
Follow-up records can be exported to a PDF from the Daily Follow-Up dashboard to create a table of the work to be performed for "offline" use.  This is intended to assist follow-up work in those situations where the Go.Data electronic solution cannot be used/is not available.

Follow-up data can also be exported to file format for exchange with other copies of Go.Data.

items.comment: Generating a paper version of the Go.Data follow-up list.

translations.french_fr: Options for getting help with Go.Data.

Getting help via the GOARN network.

translations.english_us: Installing and connecting to your copy of Go.Data.
translations.french_fr: Installing and connecting to your copy of Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
There are a number of options for setting-up and configuring Go.Data for your usage.  The tool consists of two parts: -
  1. The computer software which can be installed on Windows, Mac or Linux environments and runs on a machine.
  2. The smart phone application which runs on iPhone and Android environments and provides contact tracing functionality.
The fact that your copy of Go.Data can be set-up to exchange data with other copies of Go.Data (in a network or over the internet) means that there's a great deal of flexibility on how the tool is configured.  For example...
  1. You can simply install and run Go.Data on your own machine and work independently, taking your machine into the field for contact tracing work.
  2. You can install and run Go.Data on your own machine but ask one or more contact tracers to install the smart phone application and send you contact tracing data.
  3. You can install Go.Data on a server (rather than your own machine) and make it available to a number of users over a network - so for instance you could make your copy of Go.Data available on a local IT network in your office or over the internet and ask people to login and work with it there.
  4. You can connect together any number of local and server copies of Go.Data and have them exchange information so that data flows up from contact tracers to "consolidation" servers that pull together information.  An example would be if there was a copy of Go.Data running in each town/village in which contact tracing work is being performed but they all send their data to a single, central consolidation server which provides the overview of the whole multi-village outbreak.

items.comment: How to configure Go.Data for first usage.

translations.english_us:
Copies of Go.Data are connected together with the concept of "Upstream Servers" and "Client Application": -
  1. An upstream server is a machine TO which we wish to send a copy of the information held in our Go.Data.
  2. A client application is a machine (computer or smart phone) FROM which we will receive a copy of Go.Data information.
Upstream Servers

The platform can send data up to any number of servers. These servers can be set up clicking Upstream servers. An upstream server can collect data from any number of devices or hubs for maximum flexibility.

1. Upstream Servers page can be accessed through the main menu:
-          System Configuration - Upstream Servers

2. On this page you should see a list with the following columns:
-          Name: server identification
-          URL: Upstream server API location
-          Credentials ( Client ID & Client Secret  ): Client Application credentials
-          Description: Short description about the upstream server
-          Timeout ( milliseconds ): How long will the synchronisation system wait for sync to start processing data
-          Sync interval ( hours )
-          Sync on every change: A flag telling the synchronisation system if it should sync data on every change
-          Sync enabled: A flag telling the system if this upstream server is active

3. Visible columns
This functionality allows you to either show or hide columns displayed in the upstream server table. You can access this functionality by clicking the “3 rectangles in a line button” which is located under Main Menu button. If you click on it, you should see the list of columns
-          checked: visible
-          unchecked: hidden

You might notice that some of the columns from the table aren’t in this list ( e.g. Action column - ellipsis ). This is because these columns should always be visible.

4. Upstream server actions
Record actions can be accessed by clicking the “ellipsis” button from the right of the record.

Possible actions for upstream servers are:
-          Start sync: This action will start syncing information
-          a spinner will be visible while sync is in place. Once sync finishes, you will see the sync list again ( if you close / leave this page you won’t know anymore when the sync has finished ).
-          Disable / Enable sync:
-          Enable will be visible if upstream server is inactive ( active flag is set to false )
-          Disable will be visible if upstream server is active ( active flag is set to true )
-          Delete: This action allows you to delete upstream server.
-          As a precaution, a confirmation dialog will be displayed before actually deleting the record.

5. Create Upstream server
You can create a new Upstream server by clicking on the “Add” button from the Upstream server list page which is located on the left side of the “Selected outbreak” dropdown. All fields from this page were described above.

Client Applications

This feature is used to create credentials for client applications that are allowed to connect to this server. This must be used for mobile devices that send data to the hub, and for servers that send the data up to the consolidation Upstream servers.

1. Client Applications page can be accessed through the main menu:
- System Configuration - Client Applications
 
2. Accessing Client Applications page
On this page you should see a list with the following columns:
- Name: client application identification
- Credentials ( Client ID & Client Secret  ): Client Application credentials used for API connection by sync upstream servers
- Active: A flag telling the system if this client application is active and if it can be used for synchronisation
- Outbreaks: List of outbreaks to which sync is restricted. If no restriction is required, this can be empty 

3. Visible columns
This functionality allows you to either show or hide columns displayed in the client applications table. You can access this functionality by clicking the “3 rectangles in a line button” which is located under Main Menu button. If you click on it, you should see the list of columns
- checked: visible
- unchecked: hidden

You might notice that some of the columns from the table aren’t in this list ( e.g. Action column - ellipsis ). This is because these columns should always be visible.
 
4. Visible Columns
Record actions can be accessed by clicking the “ellipsis” button from the right of the record.
 
Possible actions for client applications are:
- Download Configuration File: This action allows you to generate a configuration qr code used by mobile apps
 
Client Application generate configuration qr code
- Disable / Enable sync:
- Enable will be visible if client application is inactive ( active flag is set to false )
- Disable will be visible if client application is active ( active flag is set to true )
- Delete: This action allows you to delete a client application.
- As a precaution, a confirmation dialog will be displayed before actually deleting the record.

5. Create Client Application
You can create a new Client application by clicking on the “Add” button from the Client Applications list page which is located on the left side of the “Selected outbreak” dropdown. All fields from this page were described above.

In case you don’t want to set something specific as in the two credentials fields, you can use the generate button to generate a random Client ID / Client Secret.

items.comment: How to connect to a copy of Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
To log in the system, go to your Hub URL and enter your user name and password, then hit Log in.

For first login, the credentials are: -

  1. USER NAME: admin@who.int
  2. PASSWORD: testtesttest
And these should be changed when first accessing the system.

If the administration password is ever lost then it can be reset on the computer on which Go.Data is running by using the Go.Data icon that appears in the system tray (at the bottom right of the screen in a Windows environment).

The system tray icon has the following application options:

  1. Open Go.Data - Opens Go.Data in a new web page
  2. Reset Admin Password - Resets the password to default
  3. Restore Backup - User can select a zip file with a backup and restore it
  4. Settings - Opens the settings to change the database port, the web app port or the encryption settings
  5. Check for updates - Checks and installs newer Go.Data versions
  6. Quit Go.Data - Quits Go.Data
The system will confirm that the password has been reset.

items.comment: Logging in to Go.Data for the first time.

translations.english_us:
A full installation manual is available for Go.Data and the procedure for installation varies depending on whether the tool is being set up on Windows, Linux or Mac OS environments or on Android or Apple smart phones.  

This manual should be consulted for a full walkthrough of installation but, in summary: -

  1. Installation on a computer is performed by running an install file.  The tool should be installed in a location to which the user has write permissions.
  2. All of Go.Data's files are installed to this location including an uninstall script.
  3. Upon first launch, the tool will ask for a number of ports - the addresses with which it communicates and whether encryption will be used for all data entered into the tool.
  4. These options can be left as default unless the user knows that the suggested, default ports are already in use.
  5. If encryption is selected then an encryption key will be generated and this should be stored and retained.
  6. The first launch of the newly-installed Go.Data will take 5 - 10 minutes as set-up completes.
  7. After this process, the login screen will appear.

For smart phones, Go.Data is installed from the AppStore/GooglePlay and the app will prompt for connection details when it first starts.  The smart phone application does not run alone and must be set-up to work with a full copy of Go.Data running on a machine.

items.comment: How to install and set-up Go.Data for the first time.

translations.english_us: An introduction to the Go.Data tool.
translations.french_fr: An introduction to the Go.Data tool.

translations.english_us:
Go.Data is a tool for outbreak investigation and contact management.  It exists to help users collect and understand data related to an outbreak involving human to human transmission, ultimately to use that data to "break the chains of transmission" and halt the spread of the disease.  It's designed for use both in the outbreak area by epidemiologists, data managers, contacts tracers and those who manage them but can also send its data to other support teams focussed purely on analysis or reporting.

To halt the spread of an infectious disease during an outbreak, epidemiologists working in the field and those that support them need (among others things) to: -

  1. Build and maintain a detailed list of all confirmed, probable and suspect cases called the case line list with strict case definitions for each classification.
  2. Build and maintain a list of all individuals that have come into contact with cases during the risk period of infection transmission.
  3. Follow up contacts on a regular basis to monitor their health status and if showing signs of illness take measures to prevent further spread of infection.
  4. Visualise the chains of transmission of the outbreak in intuitive and meaningful ways to understand what can potentially be a large and complex network of interrelated individuals.

All four activities are essential to find, identify and treat those affected and prevent further infection.

Case line list and contact tracing are most likely performed in a rapidly-changing environment with limited information available at times and so a tool to support the rapid and robust entry, validation and management of information (including sharing it with other health operatives) is critical to halting the spread of infection.

Go.Data is targeted at this community of users, working in just such an environment to assist with the work to interrupt disease transmission and therefore reduce the mortality and morbidity, the human suffering and burden associated with an infectious disease outbreak.

items.comment: An introduction and overview of Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
Go.Data's help is designed so that it can be read both chronologically (help subjects are ordered to follow in a logical sequence that will build up knowledge from start to finish) or be consulted ad-hoc for information on a specific subject as per user's current need.

A suggested reading order for a quick start understanding of Go.Data using this help system is: -
  1. Go.Data Introduction > Introduction
  2. Go.Data Introduction > Who Should Use Go.Data?
  3. Go.Data Getting Started > First Login
  4. Go.Data Getting Started > Configuring Go.Data
  5. Go.Data Outbreaks & Templates > Outbreaks
  6. Go.Data Case Management > Case line list
  7. Go.Data Case Management > Modify a case
  8. Go.Data Contact Follow-Up > Contact list
  9. Go.Data Contact Follow-Up > Modifying a contact
  10. Go.Data Best Practice > Best practice introduction
  11. Go.Data Getting Help > Help system
It is also recommended that the new user install Go.Data before they require to use it during a mission and create a "dummy" Outbreak and use that for experimentation and learning by doing.

items.comment: A quick start guide to using Go.Data and getting the most from the help.

translations.english_us:
Go.Data is designed to support contact tracing work, it's primary purpose is to collect sufficient data to model chains of transmission and allow field investigation teams to rapidly identify contacts at risk of exposure and break the chains of transmission.  It has been designed around the core concepts of an outbreak, cases, contacts and events at which cases and contacts are in close proximity.  The tool is good at modelling data in relations and generating the necessary follow-up lists to perform contact tracing work.

It is not a general purpose field investigation tool.  Although it contains form building functionality to extend the data that the tool can capture in the areas of case investigation, contact follow-up and lab sample - it should not be used for general field investigation work which does not have a contact tracing element.

The landscape of IT tools that support field work is diverse and rich and although Go.Data responds to a particular need (contact tracing), it has been built so that the data it contains can be rapidly imported/exported for exchange of information with other platforms.

Go.Data has also been built so that it can exchange its data with other copies of Go.Data so that "networks" of Go.Data instances can be built and linked together to facilitate work in teams.

items.comment: For what sorts of work is Go.Data well and not well suited?

translations.english_us:
Go.Data has been created to support the in-field work of outbreak investigation and contact tracing.  It is therefore relevant for the following types of users, and security roles have been created within the tool to organise these users and set their access permissions to the different parts of Go.Data: -

  1. Contact Tracer
  2. Contact Tracing Team Lead
  3. Data Manager
  4. Epidemiologist
  5. Administrators

In addition to this, the fact that Go.Data can export and send its data to other systems or to other copies of Go.Data means that "reporting" instances of the tool can be set-up which do not have an operational role but consolidate information for analysis, reporting and decision-making.  This widens the audience of the tool to other emergency response staff, management, researchers etc.

items.comment: A guide to the users at which Go.Data is targeted.

translations.english_us: Working with Go.Data on a mobile device/tablet.
translations.french_fr: Working with Go.Data on a mobile device/tablet.

items.comment: Working with cases on a mobile device.
Connecting your mobile copy of Go.Data to a computer copy.
Working with contacts on a mobile device.
Working with contact follow-up on a mobile device.
Getting the Go.Data application on mobile/tablet.
Working with maps on a mobile device.
Synchronising a mobile device.

translations.english_us: Working with an outbreak in Go.Data and using templates to set up outbreaks.
translations.french_fr: Working with an outbreak in Go.Data and using templates to set up outbreaks.

translations.english_us:
Although Go.Data installs with a "core" set of information to model and describe an outbreak, an administrator can create extra questions to adapt Go.Data to collect bespoke outbreak-specific data in the following three areas: -

  1. Case investigation – a set of questions that will be asked when a case investigation is recorded.
  2. Contact follow-up – a set of questions that will be asked when a contact follow-up is recorded.
  3. Lab results - a set of questions that will be asked when lab results are recorded.

A form designer exists and the following information can be set for each question.
  1. Question – text to be displayed on the form
  2. Variable – a unique identifier for the question 
  3. Category – a list of question categories
  4. Type – can be Free text, Multiple answers, Single Answer, Numeric, File Upload, Date/Time
  5. Required – if the user has to enter an answer during the form entering
Each question can be further modified, duplicated, or deleted and questions can be nested so that a set of question is only asked if the parent question is given a particular value.

The questionnaire designed in this process is delivered on the case screen, the contact follow.-up screen and the lab screen.  The questionnaires are also delivered to the smart phone application and used there.

items.comment: Designing a case investigation form in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
Although Go.Data installs with a "core" set of information to model and describe an outbreak, an administrator can create extra questions to adapt Go.Data to collect bespoke outbreak-specific data in the following three areas: -

  1. Case investigation – a set of questions that will be asked when a case investigation is recorded.
  2. Contact follow-up – a set of questions that will be asked when a contact follow-up is recorded.
  3. Lab results - a set of questions that will be asked when lab results are recorded.

A form designer exists and the following information can be set for each question.
  1. Question – text to be displayed on the form
  2. Variable – a unique identifier for the question 
  3. Category – a list of question categories
  4. Type – can be Free text, Multiple answers, Single Answer, Numeric, File Upload, Date/Time
  5. Required – if the user has to enter an answer during the form entering
Each question can be further modified, duplicated, or deleted and questions can be nested so that a set of question is only asked if the parent question is given a particular value.

The questionnaire designed in this process is delivered on the case screen, the contact follow.-up screen and the lab screen.  The questionnaires are also delivered to the smart phone application and used there.

items.comment: Designing a contact follow-up form in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
Although Go.Data installs with a "core" set of information to model and describe an outbreak, an administrator can create extra questions to adapt Go.Data to collect bespoke outbreak-specific data in the following three areas: -

  1. Case investigation – a set of questions that will be asked when a case investigation is recorded.
  2. Contact follow-up – a set of questions that will be asked when a contact follow-up is recorded.
  3. Lab results - a set of questions that will be asked when lab results are recorded.

A form designer exists and the following information can be set for each question.
  1. Question – text to be displayed on the form
  2. Variable – a unique identifier for the question 
  3. Category – a list of question categories
  4. Type – can be Free text, Multiple answers, Single Answer, Numeric, File Upload, Date/Time
  5. Required – if the user has to enter an answer during the form entering
Each question can be further modified, duplicated, or deleted and questions can be nested so that a set of question is only asked if the parent question is given a particular value.

The questionnaire designed in this process is delivered on the case screen, the contact follow.-up screen and the lab screen.  The questionnaires are also delivered to the smart phone application and used there.

items.comment: Designing a laboratory form in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
When configuring an outbreak, a tab exists to specify the Map Servers that the outbreak will use.  This is the web address (URL) of the service that will deliver map images that will be used for all geographical reports within Go.Data for that outbreak - such as the case/contact movement report, the case count map or the plot of the chains of transmission on a map.

If this tab is left blank when creating an outbreak then Go.Data will assign the default WHO map service which will deliver a grey and blue WHO basemap.

The user creating the outbreak is free however to specify any other Esri map service for the outbreak and multiple services can be chosen if the user wants, for example, to change the basemap and also add a population density layer.

In essence then, this screen gives the user flexibility to choose the starting map canvas on which Go.Data plots all of its data.

items.comment: Configuring outbreaks for map reports.

translations.english_us:
Outbreaks
This outbreaks screen available from the main menu will display the following information about all Outbreaks stored in the system:
  1. Name – the Outbreak name
  2. Disease – disease selected from Reference data
  3. Countries – countries list selected from Location data.
  4. Start Date – when the outbreak started
  5. End Date – when the outbreak ended (optional)
To add a new Outbreak, click Add button on the top of the page.

To modify an Outbreak, click the actions button to the right of the Outbreak and click Modify.

To delete an Outbreak, click the actions button to the right of the Outbreak and click Delete.

To view an Outbreak, click the actions button to the right of the Outbreak and click View.

To clone an Outbreak, click the actions button to the right of the Outbreak and click Clone.

To make an Outbreak active, click the actions button to the right of the Outbreak and click Set Active.

To see a report with data inconsistencies for an Outbreak, click the actions button to the right of the Outbreak and click View Inconsistencies.

An outbreak data can be exported by clicking Quick actions and then clicking Export Outbreak Data.

An outbreak data can be imported by clicking Quick actions and then clicking Import Outbreak Data.

This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

Selecting an Outbreak
The outbreak can be selected from the top right corner selection box.  Go.Data has the concept of the "selected" outbreak - the one that the user is currently viewing and the "active" outbreak - the one that the user is currently working upon.  Only one outbreak can be the active at any one time and a user must have an active outbreak assigned to be able to successfully connect their smart phone application to Go.Data since the smart phone application ONLY works with one outbreak at a time (the active one).

Outbreak Settings
The following information can be set for each outbreak.
  1. Name – name of the outbreak
  2. Diseases – disease from the reference data
  3. Countries – countries selected from the location data
  4. Locations – additional location selected from location data
  5. Description – verbose description
  6. Start date – when the outbreak started
  7. End date – when the outbreak has ended (optional)
  8. Case ID Mask – a mask used to generate new IDs when a case is added in the system
  9. KPIs for follow up and dashboard
  10. Case investigation – a set of questions that will be asked when a case investigation is recorded.
  11. Contact follow-up – a set of questions that will be asked when a contact follow-up is recorded.
  12. Lab results - a set of questions that will be asked when lab results are recorded.

items.comment: Working with outbreaks in Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
Templates functionality is very similar to the outbreak, except they cannot be used to collect data.   A template only exists to provide the model for creating a new outbreak and Go.Data ships with a number of pre-defined templates for common diseases and an "unknown disease" template.

An Outbreak can be quickly created from an Outbreak by clicking Action button and then clicking Generate Outbreak.

This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

items.comment: Using templates for working with outbreaks.

translations.english_us: Managing the reference data on which Go.Data relies, such as lists of locations, case classification, icons and colours etc.
translations.french_fr: Managing the reference data on which Go.Data relies, such as lists of locations, case classification, icons and colours etc.

items.comment: Extracting and re-importing reference data.
Working with icons in Go.Data.
Working with place names in Go.Data.
Adding and modifying the reference data that Go.Data uses.
Working with the list of reference data in Go.Data.

translations.english_us: Reports available within Go.Data to understand your data.
translations.french_fr: Reports available within Go.Data to understand your data.

translations.english_us:
A map of the number of cases clustered geographically is available under the Data Visualisation > Case Count Map menu item of Go.Data.

The report shows pins placed on a map (using the map server configured for the outbreak) with a count of the number of cases currently in that location.  Only cases whose current place of residence has latitude and longitude coordinates can be mapped and so the case count may be less that the actual case count for the whole outbreak.

An aggregating distance slider allows the user to chose what distance is used (in kilometres) to group the cases into the count on a single pin.

items.comment: Visualising case counts on a map.

translations.english_us:
To view the Chains of transmissions, click the menu item within Go.Data for Data Visualisation > Chains of Transmissions Graph or Data Visualisation > Chains of Transmissions List.

Chains of Transmissions Graph
The chain of transmission graph can be displayed as a Bubble network, Hierarchical network, or Timeline network for a certain date.

The following information can be customized and is using the Reference data available.
  1. Show Contacts
  2. Show Events
  3. Filter Cases by: Classification, Occupation, Gender, Name, Age, Date, Area
  4. Node color
  5. Node label
  6. Node icon
  7. Node label color
  8. Edge color
  9. Edge label

The legend can be turned on and off, and updates based on the settings of the Chain of transmission.

Chains of Transmissions Graph Drawing
Clicking on a case or contact, will list the person at the bottom of the chain of transmissions. If two persons are selected, then the create relationship form will show and enable the user to create a relationship between them.

Also, once a person is selected, the user can choose to view the details for that person, or the chain of transmissions containing that person.

Chain of Transmissions List
The chain of transmissions can be view as a list with the additional information:
  1. First contact date
  2. Root case
  3. Number of cases
  4. Number of cases alive
  5. Length
  6. Duration
Clicking on the root case will graphically display the corresponding chain of transmission only.

items.comment: Visualising the chains of transmission.

translations.english_us:
The dashboard can be viewed by selecting teh Go.Data menu item for Dashboard.  This is the default page first shown when logging in to Go.Data and shows information for the currently-selected outbreak as shown at the top-right of the page.

The following dashlets are displayed in the page to give the user an overview of the current state of the outbreak:
  1. Case summary
  2. Case by geographic location
  3. Hospitalization summary
  4. Histogram - clicking on a bar in the list will displayed the chain of transmission with that size only.
  5. Epicurve - the epicurve can be displayed by day, week, and month.
  6. Case KPIs
  7. Contact KPIs
  8. Chains of Transmission KPIs
Elements are clickable and will navigate the user to a page that shows the underlying records that contributed to the clicked graphic.  The filter used for KPIs can also be modified.

Further reports are available at the top right of the screen under the "Quick Actions" button.

items.comment: Making sense of the Go.Data start-up page.

translations.english_us:
The chain of transmission graph visualisation can be placed in "edit" mode using the toggle at the bottom right of the graphic.

When in this mode, clicking on a node (bubble) within the chain no longer shows a pop-up of information about that case/contact or event but displays a "card" for that case/contact/event at the bottom of the screen below the chains graphic.  The card has a number of action buttons that allow the user to quickly edit the selected record or filter the visualisation only on the chain that involves the selected entity.

A second entity can be selected by clicking again on the chains of transmission visualisation and this now displays two case/contact/event cards below the graphic and allows the user to create a relationship from one to another.

Edit mode is therefore a rapid and visual mechanism for working with case/contact/event data via the chains of transmission graph and quickly "wiring up" the links between bubbles.

items.comment: Working with the chains of transmission in edit mode.

translations.english_us: The hierarchical network mode of the Chains of Transmission Graph creates a tree view of the cases/contacts/events involved in the currently-selected outbreak to try to give a sense of the flow of infectious transmission over timefrom node to node.

items.comment: Visualising  the chain of transmission as a hierarchy.

translations.english_us:
A map view of the chain of transmission is available under the Go.Data menu item Data Visualisation > Geospatial Map.

This screen uses the map server configured for the current outbreak to deliver a map (and any additional data layers requested when the outbreak was set up) and then to plot the current chain of transmission on top of that.  For this graphic to work, cases/contacts and events in the chain must have latitude/longitude coordinates for their current place of residence (or the location of the event) so that they can be geolocalised.

items.comment: Visualising  the chains of transmission on a map.

translations.english_us:
Three timeline views of the chain of transmission graph are available: -
  1. Timeline by date of onset
  2. Timeline by date of last contact
  3. Timelines by date of reportion
These generate either a vertical or horizontal timeline with dates plotted and the nodes (bubbles) representing cases/contacts and events displayed next to the appropriate date.

This view is particularly useful for trying to assess the temporal spread of a disease.

items.comment: Visualising the chains of transmission as a timeline.

translations.english_us: Tackling problems and issues when using Go.Data.
translations.french_fr: Tackling problems and issues when using Go.Data.

items.comment: Issues encountered when installing Go.Data.

translations.english_us: Go.Data does not show my data
translations.french_fr: Go.Data does not show my data

items.comment: What to do if you suspect missing data.
Issues when starting up Go.Data.
What to do if Go.Data has issues connecting to other instances.
What to do if Go.Data crashes during use.

translations.english_us: I can't connect my mobile phone/tablet
translations.french_fr: I can't connect my mobile phone/tablet

items.comment: What to do if you can't connect your contact tracing device.

translations.english_us: Security in Go.Data and setting up user accounts.
translations.french_fr: Security in Go.Data and setting up user accounts.

translations.english_us:
Users of Go.Data can be grouped in to Teams for management of contact tracing activity.  Teams are assigned to one or more locations and the follow-up for any contact whose present address is in that location will automatically be assigned to the team.

A teams options exists in the menu under Admin > Teams & Assignments in which an administrator can set-up the teams, allocate the members of the team and choose one or more locations in which that team will be active.

A workload report is available as a Quick Action from the Teams & Assignment page to see how much folow-up work each team has been assigned on a day by day basis.

Users can open and modify any follow-up record to assign it to a different team if workload is to be balanced manually.

items.comment: Grouping users in to teams for the purpose of contact tracing.

translations.english_us:
A dedicated screen for managing the users of Go.Data exists under Admin > Users and users can also manage their own profile by clicking on their email at the top of the menu.

The user management screen will show the list of users that exist in the system. Any number of user can be created, and each users can have its own user roles assigned to it.

This screen will display the following information about each User in the system:
  1. Last Name
  2. First Name
  3. Email – will be used to connect
  4. Roles – a set of roles assigned to that user
  5. Outbreaks – a set of available outbreaks that user can access.
This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

To add a new user, click Add button on the top of the page.
To modify a user, click the actions button to the right of the user and click Modify.
To delete a user, click the actions button to the right of the user and click Delete.
To view a user, click the actions button to the right of the user and click View.

Each user will have one Active Outbreak. This outbreak has to be set from the Add/Modify User screen. 

To reset the password for a user, you have to also access the Add/Modify User screen.

items.comment: Managing the list of users that can access Go.Data.

translations.english_us:
The security roles which control what a user is allowed to do within Go.Data are administered from the screen available via menu option Admin > Roles. This screen will show the list of user roles that exist in the system. Any number of user roles can be created, and each role can have its own permissions.

This screen will display the following information about each User Role in the system:
  1. Name – a relevant name for the role like Admin, Contact Tracer, etc.
  2. Description – a verbose description of the Role. (for example: Assign this role to people that are collecting data in the field)
  3. Options – a set of predefined system permissions assign to the role.
This list can be sorted by clicking the top name of the column, and be filtered by entering filter information underneath the column name. If you want to go back to the initial state, press Reset button. Press Refresh if you want to get latest data from the database.

To add a new role, click Add button on the top of the page.

To modify a role, click the actions button to the right of the role and click Modify.

To delete a role, click the actions button to the right of the role and click Delete.

To view a role, click the actions button to the right of the role and click View.

items.comment: How does Go.Data use roles and permissions to enforce security?

translations.english_us:
Go.Data controls access by requiring that a user name and password be provided for login.  After first install of the system only a single administrator account (admin@who.int) with a defailt password (testtesttest) is present and this can be reset (on a computer) using the system tray icon at the bottom right (on a Windows machine) of the screen.

An administrator has a Users screen for managing the list of users and this controls access both to the computer version of Go.Data and any smart phone applications that connect to that computer.

Options for managing users and all other security-related information are found under the Admin menu within Go.Data.

Administrators are free to create as many user accounts as they wish and can also reset passwords on behalf of users.  Users can request a password reset themselves also, either by requesting an email (Go.Data must be configured to use an email server for this) or by responding to a set of "security questions" such as "where was your first school?".  These security questions must have been set-up in advance by the user.

At first login all users must reset their password for best practice.

Access to functionality in Go.Data is managed by assigning users to one or more "roles" with role names such as "administrator", "data manager", "contact tracer".  Roles actually translate to permissions to perform particular business functions within Go.Data.  Go.Data installs with a small set of default suggested roles but an Administrator is able to create new custom roles as they require.

items.comment: How does Go.Data handle different types of users?
